steps.title: Understanding Excel Functions
steps.content:
What is a Function?

For this set of activities, you will need the functions_and_charts file.

This can be found in the FUNCTIONS & CHARTS section under the Excel Skills page on Aidan's Central.

A function in Excel is a predefined formula that performs calculations using specific values in a particular order. Think of functions as shortcuts for common or complex calculations.

The Structure of a Function

Every Excel function follows this basic structure:

=FUNCTION_NAME(Argument1, Argument2, ...)

This structure consists of:

  • The equals sign (=) which tells Excel you are starting a formula.
  • The Function Name (e.g., SUM, AVERAGE) which is the action you want to perform.
  • Arguments inside parentheses, which are the inputs for the function, such as numbers, cell references, or text.

Common Functions We'll Use

  • SUM: Adds all numbers in a range.
  • COUNTA: Counts how many non-empty cells are in a range.
  • MAX: Returns the largest value in a range.
  • MIN: Returns the smallest value in a range.

quiz.question: What symbol must you start with when writing a function in Excel?

steps.title: Practice: Using SUM and COUNTA
steps.content:
Adding Numbers and Counting Cells

Practice Exercise

Using the 'functions_and_charts' sheet, we will calculate the 'Total Units Sold' and the 'Number of Products'.

1. Calculate Total Units Sold with SUM

The SUM function adds all numeric values in a range of cells.

  1. Click on cell C12, next to 'Total Units Sold:'.
  2. Type the following formula and press Enter:
=SUM(C2:C9)

This formula adds up all the numbers in the 'Units Sold' column.

2. Count Products with COUNTA

The COUNTA function counts any cell that is not empty. It's great for counting items in a list.

  1. Click on cell C13, next to 'Number of Products:'.
  2. Type the following formula and press Enter:
=COUNTA(A2:A9)

This formula counts every product name listed in column A.

SUM vs. COUNTA

Remember, SUM adds numbers together, while COUNTA just counts how many cells have something in them. The SUM of prices would be a large number, but the COUNTA of prices would just be the number of products with a price listed.

quiz.question: Which function would you use to count how many cells in a list of names contain any data?

steps.title: Practice: Using MAX and MIN
steps.content:
Finding Highest and Lowest Values

1. Find the Highest Price with MAX

The MAX function finds the largest number in a range of cells.

  1. Click on cell C14, next to 'Highest Price Per Unit:'.
  2. Type the following formula and press Enter:
=MAX(D2:D9)

This will find the highest value in the 'Price Per Unit' column.

2. Find the Lowest Price with MIN

The MIN function finds the smallest number in a range.

  1. Click on cell C15, next to 'Lowest Price Per Unit:'.
  2. Type the following formula and press Enter:
=MIN(D2:D9)

This will find the lowest value in the same column.

quiz.question: If you wanted to find the highest value in both columns C and D, which formula would you use?

steps.title: Creating Charts
steps.content:
Visualizing Data with Charts

Charts are powerful tools for turning numbers into an easy-to-understand visual story. Let's create a chart to compare the revenue of each product.

How to Create a Column Chart

  1. Select the data you want to chart. For this, click cell A1, hold Shift, and click cell A9. Then, hold Ctrl and select from E1 to E9. This selects the 'Product' and 'Total Revenue' columns, including their headers.
  2. Go to the Insert tab on the ribbon.
  3. In the Charts group, click the 'Recommended Charts' button.
  4. Choose the first option, '2-D Clustered Column'.

Customizing Your Chart

Once your chart is created, you can easily customize it.

  • Chart Title: Double-click the title to rename it to something descriptive, like 'Total Revenue by Product'.
  • Add/Remove Elements: Click on the chart, then click the green + button that appears on the right to add data labels, axis titles, and more.
  • Change Style/Colors: With the chart selected, use the Chart Design tab that appears in the ribbon to quickly change the look and feel.

quiz.question: Which chart type is best for showing how different parts make up a total (e.g., each product's revenue as a percentage of all revenue)?
